bestBHT.bht: Leaving Nazareth, Jesus made his home in Capernaum, a central and populous town on the borders of the lake of Gennesaret. It was the residence of four of the Apostles and became known as His own city. Capernaum was chosen by Jesus for various reasons - it was a political and commercial center, a fishing mart where Gentiles frequented, and it provided a better chance for spreading the message of the kingdom compared to Jerusalem or Nazareth. In Capernaum, Jesus settled and established himself, despite being rejected by his own townsmen in Nazareth.

Henry Alford: Leaving Nazareth, this town, on the borders of the lake of Gennesareth, was central in situation, and in the most populous and frequented part of Galilee."
It besides was the residence of four at least of the Apostles, Andrew and Peter, and James and John—and probably of Matthew.
It is from this time called ‘His own city.’
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Leaving Nazareth... he came and dwelt in Capernaum."
Our Lord seems to have chosen it for several reasons.
But one other high reason for the choice of Capernaum remains to be mentioned, the only one specified by our Evangelist.
Albert Barnes: Leaving Nazareth - Because his townsmen cast him out, and rejected him.
The exact site of this ancient city has been a question of much interest, and is not supposed to be as yet fully settled; perhaps it is not possible that it should be.
Jesus came and lived in the boundaries or regions of Zabulon and Naphthali.
John Calvin: Though the whole nation...death will be more tolerable than the previous diseases were.
Certainly, it is evident from the context, that the prophet looks much farther...to whom the darkness of death would be changed into the light of life.

Now, we know that the kingdom of Christ is spiritual...The prophet’s discourse relates, no doubt, to the destruction of the nation, but presents to us, as in a mirror, what is the condition of mankind, until they are delivered by the grace of Christ.
Philip Schaff: And leaving Nazareth, His early home. Because rejected there.
Came and dwelt, or having come he settled.
Capernaum was an important place, the residence of Andrew, Peter, and the sons of Zebedee, probably of Matthew also, chiefly honored by the title, 'His own city'.
Archibald T. Robertson: In Capernaum (probably the modern Τελλ Hυμ) Jesus was in a large town, one of the centres of Galilean political and commercial life, a fishing mart, where many Gentiles came.
Here the message of the kingdom would have a better chance than in Jerusalem with its ecclesiastical prejudices or in Nazareth with its local jealousies.
John Gill: Whilst the consolation of Israel dwelt there.
They represent the inhabitants of it as very great sinners, heretics, and dealers in magic art.
Thus they show their spite against the very place in which Christ dwelt.
John Wesley: Leaving Nazareth — Namely, when they had wholly rejected his word, and even attempted to kill him, Luke 4:29.

bhtAttempts.bht: Leaving Nazareth, Jesus made his home in Capernaum, a central and populous town on the borders of the lake of Gennesaret. It was the residence of four of the Apostles and became known as His own city. Capernaum was chosen by Jesus for various reasons - it was a political and commercial center, a fishing mart where Gentiles frequented, and it provided a better chance for spreading the message of the kingdom compared to Jerusalem or Nazareth. In Capernaum, Jesus settled and established himself, despite being rejected by his own townsmen in Nazareth.

Leaving Nazareth, Jesus chose to make his home in Capernaum, a central and populous town on the borders of the lake of Gennesaret, known as His own city. Capernaum offered several advantages, including its location in the most frequented part of Galilee, the presence of four Apostles, and its status as a political and commercial center. Furthermore, Capernaum provided a better opportunity to reach both Jews and Gentiles with the message of the kingdom. Despite rejection in Nazareth, Jesus established himself in Capernaum.

Leaving Nazareth, Jesus made his home in Capernaum, a central and populous town on the borders of the lake of Gennesaret. It was the residence of four at least of the Apostles, and probably of Matthew as well. Jesus chose Capernaum for several reasons, including its political and commercial significance as a fishing mart, where many Gentiles came. This strategic location provided a better opportunity to spread the message of the kingdom compared to Jerusalem or Nazareth.

Leaving his hometown of Nazareth behind, Jesus settled in Capernaum, a central and populous town on the shores of the lake of Gennesaret. This was a strategic choice for several reasons. Capernaum was not only a hub of Galilean political and commercial life, but it was also a fishing mart that attracted many Gentiles. Jesus purposely chose this location, as it provided a better chance to spread the message of the kingdom, free from ecclesiastical prejudices in Jerusalem and local jealousies in Nazareth.

Choosing Capernaum over his hometown of Nazareth, Jesus settled in this central and populous town on the borders of the lake of Gennesaret. Capernaum served as a political and commercial center and was a fishing mart that drew many Gentiles. It provided a strategic location for Jesus to spread the message of the kingdom, free from the religious biases and local rivalries found in Jerusalem and Nazareth. Jesus purposefully made his home in Capernaum, establishing himself in a place that would have a better chance for success.
